What

Monochromatic violet light is definitely purple-ish looking, in spite of the fact that actual purple is a mix of colours. Violet is not just "dark blue".

It's true that you can't properly show violet light on a typical RGB display, so if showing violet on a display, you would fake it with a very bluish purple, because that's the closest you can simulate how we perceive violet without actually creating violet light.

Look at a 400nm LED sometime, (often called UV, though it's really just violet). They have no red light in the mix, but definitely look violet (and not blue).

Great explanation on the origins of different colours as mixtures of different portions of monochromatic lights using the chromatographic diagram! And I did learn the reason for why stars are not purple in colour with the thermal spectrum. It might even be better if the effect of scattering by the Earth's atmosphere to the sun's original spectrum is shown at the end. That will be a more explicit way of showing that scattering (by the atmosphere) cannot modify the spectrum in a way that gives the "right" proportion leading to purple/violet, and hence the sky is not purple/violet. I can see violet in a prism. When I was in elementary school I remember the teacher showing us a prism and identifying the seven colors to us. I asked what that 8th color was and pointed at it. She said it was blue. I said, "no, that really thin line right past blue." And she gave me a funny face and then ignore the question and moved on. It wasn't until years later that I learned that it wasn't normal to see 8 colors in a rainbow. It just so happens that I can see a wider range of colors than other people can. Whereas some people are tetrachromatic, having an additional cone oh, I'm not. I just have a larger frequency range. One benefit of this is having Perfect Color acuity. Because I can distinguish a wider frequency band I can see differences in colors that other people can't. So in short, yeah, it is possible to see purple without mixing with other colors. It's just not a common ability.

I can't always differentiate between the blue and purple in a rainbow in the sky though for some reason. It is a really thin line to me, so sometimes it's just seven colors. Although, sometimes I even see 14 to 16 color rainbows, as I can occasionally see the colors blending together. That's distinct from the 14 to 16 color rainbows where the color pattern is inverted onto itself for some reason.

No, violet light is a thing. Violet falls between blue and purple on a color diagram. It's not just "dark blue" nor is it purple. Red, is right out. And violets are violet, not blue. In addition, non-colorblind humans can see violet light, so this isn't a mystery. Some animals can even see ultraviolet frequencies...not humans sadly, and ultraviolet isn't simply more violet than regular violet, it's the range of frequencies after violet light, so it's not violet at all. But violet light still exists in any case. #violetisnotblue

Violet is not dark blue.  You can observe this for yourself with a 400nm LED.  Violet is violet.  It is quite distinct from blue.

So, Henry, when you claim that violet is not a monochromatic color, you seem to be forgetting that monochromatic violet lasers exist... and look purple, not blue. Spectral violet is a real monochromatic colour, despite the couple of videos you made saying the opposite :). There is a second small peak in the sensitivity of our red color receptors in the far blue region, so very short wavelength light gets picked up by both the blue and the red receptors, and looks violet (purple, not blue). Your photos of refracted light won't show this because the red sensors/filters in cameras don't have this second peak in the blue that human red cones have. For a similar reason, computer screens cannot show real monochromatic violet, they have to fake it.

Violate "exists", that is, it's a actual spectrum of light, whereas "purple" does not exist. When we see purple, we're really seeing red light and blue light in roughly equal intensities. We create "purple" inside our heads.

Spectral violet consists of single wavelengths that create a combination of red and blue perceptions in the human visual system. However in a digital camera these wavelengths only affect the short wavelength (Blue) sensor and not the long wavelength (Red) one, so they photograph as deep blue. I don't know why anyone would say that spectral violet is actually a deep blue unless they need to look at a real spectrum instead of relying on photos.

Roses are red.
Violets are blue.
Black lights are violet.
Violet's not blue.

Of course, sunlight doesn't emit a lot of violet, and the air attenuates it further, as do most other "transparent" materials. Anything that reflected pure violet but not red would probably end up looking very dark, both because our eyes don't perceive it very well, and there just aren't that many violet photons flying around under normal conditions to reflect into our eyes. In reality, most violet dyes are actually purple.


On the other hand, take this image of a rainbow, from Wikipedia:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rainbow#mediaviewer/File:WhereRainbowRises.jpg

Or this image, also from wiki, of the emission spectrum of a black light.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_light#mediaviewer/File:Fluorescent_Black-Light_spectrum_with_peaks_labelled.gif


Now, if we look at a black light, it is obviously violet, no question, and yet, it emits no red light? How can this be? Because violet doesn't actually look blue, it looks purple (ish).
Except that you do see violet in prismatic rainbows. Look at the image there? Given, you see purple, not violet, but it's there.

Uh.... violet does actually exist as a frequency of light. Purple-looking violet.
Anyone who's tried putting a royal blue LED in liquid nitrogen knows this.

Or for that matter, anyone who owns a 380–450 nm actual violet LED. They look purple, and the reflections off of white objects look REALLY purple. They aren't purple, they are violet, but they look that way. It is actually not possible to reproduce real violet on a computer monitor, despite it taking up 25.4% of the logarithmic size of the human visual range. (380-740 nm).

That's almost as big as red. Much larger than orange and yellow combined, larger than green, larger than blue, larger than blue or green including cyan. It's the second-largest part of the visual spectrum to have a name for the color, and yet you deny it exists?

This video answers a question different than the one asked. It answers why there aren't purple hot objects and it gives the wrong answer to both questions.

The reason the sky is blue and not purple is the relative sensitivity of the eye to different wavelengths of light and the details of the solar spectrum (which the video does touch upon). The spectrum of the scattered light is a solar spectrum distorted by the scattering process. This process is very inefficient for red light (long wavelength) and much more efficient for blue light (short wavelength). This produces a spectrum that is predominantly blue and purple. The reason that it isn't mostly purple is the fact that the solar spectrum drops off quickly add to that the fact that the human eye is much less sensitive to purple light than blue and we get the blue sky we see.

The reason we see a blue sky and not a purple one is the small amount of purple light coupled with the low sensitivity of our eyes to that light.
Finally!! I've wanted a non-technical answer to this question for years!

Here is something i just wrote up please tell me via reply if it was a good "essay"I Wonder?

I wonder what the past lives have seen and heard when gazing upon the vast night sky filled with bright fluorescent balls of plasma held together by their own gravity. Today when we look up at the night sky all we hear is the distant sound of automobiles and we see the faint shine of the stars. The best way to see these plasma masses burning bright in the distance is to get as far away from civilization as possible. The lights of all the cars, buildings, and houses ruin the ambiance of the night sky. I wonder what the humans in the past heard, the chatter of friends and family along with the faint howling of wolves and dogs reaching out to the moon. Or did they hear nothing just the breeze as it gently blows across the dark silhouettes of trees and valleys of nothing but grass and a tree here and there. But complete silence fills in the empty spaces of when the breeze grows calm. They gaze up to see the brightness and colorful stars. They can feel the earth rotating under their feet and realize the size of the darkness that is space. The distant galaxies and planets across the vast abyss with no bridge long enough to span the chasm. It almost seems the darkness is infinite. With the earth being a spec floating in an endless room with no walls or floors. A tiny part of space. Would the darkness care if one planet disappeared, or will the vast space be enough to fulfill it and not even care, maybe not even realize that it was gone. Many questions have been brought to the attention of space, but we can not grasp the infinite darkness and endless rooms that we revolve in. There are really no definite answers to this topic. What we do know is this, we never had the intention of taking it all in at the same time, time is what we need, take things in a little at a time. This arouses the question of time. Does time really exist? Does it matter to the outer darkness of space, or does the darkness just revolve around nothingness? These questions can never really be answered so soon. We must take time to find out. Or will we find out? These questions need time to answer and i'm sure a million years from now there will be an answer. Sadly humans probably will not be around to hear it. Maybe a different life form will exist doing what i am exactly doing, asking questions. We will never find out. This is just something that we will have to keep asking questions about. The answer will surface when the time is right and we have waited long enough. But sadly today is not that day these questions will be answered. I wonder when?

I always thought that the sun was yellow because it's max wavelength emitted was around 570 nm ie yellow. And for it to be white it would have to emit equal amounts of red blue and green. And from the spectrum you can see the area counts aren't equivalent

It is too bad we cannot produce computer monitors that can stretch farther out into the color spectrum, and also explains why a picture of a black light never truly captures the deep violet color it can produce (pure 400nm wavelength).

I wonder if AMOLED displays can actually display a much broader array of colors since the light sources are individual LEDs themselves. Also, what about people with tetrachromatic vision, how do led monitors look to their eyes? If there forth color receptor is, say, yellow, then they will be able to notice a huge difference in color between actual yellow wavelengths of light (like from a prism) and the mixture of red and green most everyone else can see. It would be like the difference between some shade of purplish washed-out yellow and some neon yellow, I'd imagine. (the tetrachromats  wouldn't be able to describe the difference to use since they have learned since birth that everything of that basic hue is yellow, so they would not be able to differentiate it by description, even if they did, it would be like tring to describe the difference between red and green to a colorblind person. They do not have any conceptual understanding of those hues.) So in a way we are all colorblind!

I'd like to quickly point out that the diagram at around 2:00 is slightly inaccurate; at higher temperatures, a black body will emit more light at all wavelengths, so the curve will be entirely above the colder curve. The main idea, that the maximum will shift toward higher frequency, was still there, but still, I think it's worth mentioning.

To a commenter below (Pseu Donymous), the truth is that when you look at a telescope from Earth, the sun appears yellowish in colour (and you'll see sunspots) due to the earth's atmosphere.
In actual fact, images of the sun you see by various people can be taken with filters of a specific frequency, such as UV/IR (Very vague here but the frequency is more specific than a big range) which sometimes makes the sun appear blue/green/any other non-orangeyellow colour. On the Visible scale, however, the sun produces a tiny bit more yellow light but it is insufficient and therefore looks white (even from space with the naked eye). More often than not the images of the sun online have been colour-corrected to suit the usual colour that we are all used to- orange.

Okay so if the scattering is the only thing that's causing redness, why is the sky red at a sunset? I'd expect the sun to be red, but the sky directly around it to be blue, with this explanation. Because, the sky around the sun would then show the light scattered from the sunlight. And sometimes not just the sky near the sun, but also the whole rest of the western horizon will be red. Surely the rest should still be blue, since there is no direct light being emitted anywhere near the north-west part of the horizon.

Whats this? I can see violet (purple kind of violet) in the spectrum. And there are chromaticity diagrams with the violet end, not just this blue one in the video.

Henry:

The disclaimer you added @0:59 actually contradicts your claim that the color at the short end is blue.

Note that our monitors can only render within that triangle.  But note also that it's an exact triangle--the lines are exactly straight.  That's because these chromaticity diagrams are such that the linear combination of any two colors on the diagram forms a third color in a straight line.

But the blue point on your triangle, projected backwards from white, only manages to hit about 465nm on your diagram.  So, sure, we can't render 465nm light's color--but 465nm light blended only with white is perfectly renderable--and becomes blue.  In like fashion, how do you imagine we should render 400nm light's approximate color on a monitor?

Easy.  By taking blue and adding... red.

Yeah, I know.  It sounds confusing, but it's not as big a deal as you think.  L cones don't produce red percepts--rather, ganglia in our eyes adds L and subtracts out M, forming the red-green opponent color process.  This moves towards red when L dominates this process and, since M falls off in sensitivity faster than L near the short wavelengths, the process tends back towards red.

I guess if our eyes were more sensitive on the "blue" end, or the curve would be steeper, the sky would be darker, towards violet (or dark blue). Maybe that is what is happening, as there are individual differences between people and they are just used to their "blue". Would not surprise me as I read somwhere that according to one study some people were able to see frequencies up to 1020 nm, which is in the near infrared part of electromagnetic spectrum. Althought I imagine they were "seeing" only monochromatic IR light of that frequency, and it must have been a very intense light, but they saw just some dim, very dark red and hard to recognize outlines. If they were looking at the full visible light spectrum, the IR fequencies would be effectively blocked by the processing of visible light. Might be interesting though to take part in such an experiment. I would certainly volunteer.
